Top-3 Scripts:
su_1225888: ChrootDirectory
         Specifies the pathname of a directory to chroot(2) to after
         authentication.  At session startup sshd(8) checks that all
         components of the pathname are root-owned directories which are
         not writable by any other user or group.  After the chroot,
         sshd(8) changes the working directory to the user's home
         directory.

Do not automatically hard-wrap the current line when it becomes overlong. This is
 the default. (This option is the opposite of -b (--breaklonglines) - the last one
 given takes effect.)

Explanations about Options.-geometry:
This option specifies the preferred size and position of the VTxxx window; see
 X(7).
Explanations about Options.-e:
This option specifies the program (and its command line arguments) to be run in
 the xterm window. It also sets the window title and icon name to be the basename
 of the program being executed if neither -T nor -n are given on the command line.

Answers.MP Summary: or  any situation  where  you want to make sure you're doing a clean install of your dependencies. It  can  be  significantly  faster  than  a  regular  npm  install  by  skipping   certain user-oriented  features.  It  is  also  more strict than a regular install, which can help catch errors or inconsistencies caused by the incrementally-installed  local  environments of most npm users. In short, the main differences between using npm install and npm ci are: · The project must have an existing package-lock.json or npm-shrinkwrap.json. · If dependencies in the package lock do not match those in package.json, npm ci will exit with an error, instead of updating the package lock. · npm ci can only install entire projects at a time:  individual  dependencies  cannot  be added with this command. · If  a  node_modules  is  already present, it will be automatically removed before npm ci begins its install. · It will  never  write  to  package.json  or  any  of  the  package-locks:  installs  are essentially frozen. See Also · npm help install · npm help package-locks April 2020                                  NPM-CI(1)

su_1225888: ChrootDirectory
         Specifies the pathname of a directory to chroot(2) to after
         authentication.  At session startup sshd(8) checks that all
         components of the pathname are root-owned directories which are
         not writable by any other user or group.  After the chroot,
         sshd(8) changes the working directory to the user's home
         directory.

date
touch /tmp/testFile
'

Top-3 Similar Questions: ul_519992: Restricting a user to a certain directory on SSH login
Top-3 Scripts:
ul_519992: mkdir -p /home/test

mkdir -p /home/test/dev/        
cd /home/test/dev/
mknod -m 666 null c 1 3
mknod -m 666 tty c 5 0
mknod -m 666 zero c 1 5
mknod -m 666 random c 1 8

chown root:root /home/test
chmod 0755 /home/test

mkdir -p /home/test/bin
cp -v /bin/bash /home/test/bin/

ldd /bin/bash
mkdir -p /home/test/lib64
cp -v /lib64/{libtinfo.so.5,libdl.so.2,libc.so.6,ld-linux-x86-64.so.2} /home/test/lib64/

mkdir /home/test/etc
cp -vf /etc/{passwd,group} /home/test/etc/

#define username to apply chroot jail to
Match User sshguest
#specify chroot jail
ChrootDirectory /home/test

mkdir -p /home/test/home/tecmint
chown -R sshguest:sshguest /home/test/home/sshguest
chmod -R 0700 /home/test/home/sshguest

cp -v /bin/ls /home/test/bin/
ldd /bin/ls
cp -v /lib64/{libselinux.so.1,libcap.so.2,libacl.so.1,libc.so.6,libpcre.so.1,libdl.so.2,ld-linux-x86-64.so.2,libattr.so.1,libpthread.so.0} /home/test/lib64/
### or whatever directory and libs you need on your system
